721.13   Service call cancellation.
721.14   Equipment requirements.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Towing requirements - see TRAF.
339.07
 
721.01  DEFINITIONS.
   Words and terms used in these regulations are defined as follows:
   (a)   “Driver or operator” means a person who drives or is in actual
physical control of a tow truck on a public street or public right of way in
the Village.
   (b)   “Person” means an individual, firm, co-partnership, association or
corporation.
   (c)   “Tow truck” means a truck or any other vehicle adapted or used for the
purpose of towing, winching or otherwise removing disabled motor vehicles for
commercial purposes.
   (d)   “Towing firm or tow truck owner” means an individual, partnership,
corporation, fiduciary, association or other entity owning, operating or
conducting the business of towing vehicles.
   (e)   “Towing” means the act of pulling or dragging a vehicle behind the tow
truck which is doing such pulling or dragging.  Towing also includes flat bed
towing.  The towed vehicle can be self-supporting, carried on a flat bed, dolly
type platform or supported on any other item necessary to facilitate such
towing.
   (f)   “Vehicle” means any motorized equipment licensed under the laws of the
State of Ohio or any similar licensing laws of any other state of the United
States.
   (g)   “License” means any license, permit or authority required by the
Village for towing vehicles.
   (h)   “Premises” means the location upon which the main office of a towing
firm or tow truck owner is located and/or towed vehicles are stored or
impounded.
   (j)   “Storage” means the custody and control of a vehicle by a tow truck
operator.
      (Ord. 35-89.  Passed 5-15-89.)
721.02  LICENSE REQUIRED.
   (a)   In any situation involving a motor vehicle, where because of accident,
emergency, absent owner or operator or when required by law or ordinance the
vehicle must be removed from a location, towed and stored, and the owner or
operator cannot or does not exercise a preference for a towing service the
Village will provide for such service for the owner or operator by a towing
firm licensed pursuant to this chapter.
 
   (b)   Whenever a police officer requests a motor vehicle to be towed and
impounded, for evidence, only towing firms licensed by the Village shall be
used.
(Ord. 35-89.  Passed 5-15-89.)
721.03  LICENSE REQUIREMENTS.
   Every towing firm or operator applying for a license to provide towing
service for the Village shall meet the following minimum requirements:
   (a)   Every licensee shall maintain liability insurance with the following
minimum limits of coverage:
      (1)   Bodily injury and property damage with combined single limit of one
million dollars ($1,000,000) per person/per occurrence.
      (2)   On Hook coverage - seventy-five thousand dollars ($75,000) per
occurrence.
      (3)   Garage keepers legal liability with a minimum of seventy-five
thousand dollars ($75,000) coverage.
   A certificate of insurance shall accompany any application for a license and
shall show the expiration date and contain a provision that the policy may not
be cancelled or not renewed without at least a ten day notice to the Village of
Lordstown.  The policy shall indemnify the Village of Lordstown, its officers,
agents and employees and any and all third persons from loss or damage by
reason of any negligent or unlawful act omitted or performed by the licensee,
its agents or employees in conjunction with the towing or storage of any
vehicle in response to a Village initiated call.  Failure to have proper
insurance in effect at any time shall constitute grounds for immediate and
nonappealable suspension of a license.  Cancellation of any insurance policy
more than two times within a one year period may be grounds for suspension and
cancellation of the license.
 
   (b)   No person shall be licensed who has had two or more theft convictions
within the last ten years immediately preceding application.
 
   (c)   The applicant for a license, including any partner or limited partner
of a limited partnership and any officer or director of a corporate applicant,
shall furnish the following information:
      (1)   Name and address.
      (2)   The location of the premises for which the license is requested.
      (3)   The length of time applicant has been engaged in the business of
towing vehicles.
      (4)   Telephone numbers of the applicant and business telephone numbers
currently in use.
      (5)   The applicant’s physical description including weight, color of
eyes, color of hair and date of birth.
      (6)   The business, occupation or employment of the applicant for the
three years immediately preceding the date of the application.
      (7)   Criminal history information, including date, time and place of
convictions for all violations except traffic offenses.
      (8)   A set of fingerprints obtained by the Police Department and a
recent two inch by two inch color photograph of the applicant.
      (9)   If the applicant is a corporation, or a partnership which is
incorporated, the name of the corporation shall be set forth exactly as shown
on the articles of incorporation
      (10)   A list of all employees operating tow trucks along with a copy of
their operator’s license. Licensees must submit copies of operator’s licenses
of all new employees to the Police Department.
      (11)   A list of towing rates for services which shall include the
following:
         A.   Towing of passenger vehicles, small trucks or vans;
         B.   The unhooking of linkage when keys are not available;
         C.   Use of dollies;
         D.   Stuck vehicle, removing no towing;
         E.   Heavy towing, large vehicles or truck, use of heavy equipment;
         F.   Regular tow, large vehicle;
         G.   Stuck large vehicle or truck requiring lifting;
         H.   Standard motorist tow;
         I.   Standard motorist flat;
         J.   Standard motorist start.
      (12)   Applicants’ rates shall not be more than the regularly established
rate for such service.  Fees that do not reflect this rate, may be grounds for
denial of the license.
      (13)   Failure to comply with the rules of this section shall be grounds
for the revocation of license.
      (14)   No license issued pursuant to this section shall be assigned or
transferred to any other tow truck, persons or towing firm.
         (Ord. 51-2003.  Passed 8-11-03.)
721.04  PREMISES.
   (a)   Premises, including office and storage lot and other facilities shall
be located within four miles of the center of the Village of Lordstown (S.R. 45
and Salt Springs Road) with twenty-four hour service and telephone
communication.
 
   (b)   Premises must have the capability of allowing the police dispatcher to
call one emergency number to contact the towing firm for a police tow, twenty-
four hours a day.  In the event there is no answer within ten rings or the line
is busy, the dispatcher will repeat the call.  If the line is still busy, or no
answer within ten rings, the dispatcher will call the next towing firm on the
list.
 
   (c)   Premises shall be fenced, and well lit.  Outside storage lot shall
have enough space to hold not less than twenty Village police tows. Outside
storage lot should also be capable of storing tractor trailers.
 
   (d)   Premises shall have suitable covered garage space with storage
capacity of at least two vehicles and with a hydraulic rack of comparable
equipment that would permit thorough undercarriage investigation of a vehicle.
 
   (e)   The towing service must be available twenty-four hours a day 365 days
a year so as to be capable of responding to emergency calls and being on the
scene within fifteen minutes of the call.
 
   (f)   The towing service must be available for inspection of vehicles by
members of the Police Department at any time.
 
   (g)   The towing service must be able to release towed vehicles during
normal business hours. 
(Ord. 35-89.  Passed 5-15-89.)
721.05  EQUIPMENT.
   Equipment shall consist of at least:
   (a)   A tow truck with a manufacturer rated chassis one ton or more or
equivalent gross vehicle weight, equipped with a winch and boom, manufacturer
rated at four ton capacity, with cable having a minimum diameter of 3/8 inch.
   (b)   All vehicles shall be equipped with the name and phone number of the
towing company on each side of the vehicle with a minimum of three inch
letters.  Each vehicle shall have a six inch identification number on each
fender and on the left rear of cab.
   (c)   All vehicles must be equipped with two-way communication, capable of
communications from the Village to the premises.
   (d)   Vehicles are required to carry the equipment listed under equipment
requirements.  Vehicles may be required to carry additional equipment as
prescribed by the Chief of Police.
   (e)   All vehicles shall meet all other requirements of State law or
ordinances of the Village. 
(Ord. 35-89.  Passed 5-15-89.)
721.06  APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; FEE.
   (a)   Application for a towing license shall be made to the Mayor upon forms
prepared and approved by him.
 
   (b)   The application shall be accompanied by a fee of one hundred dollars
($100.00) to cover the costs of required inspection and processing.
 
   (c)   Upon receipt of an application the Mayor shall refer it to the Police
Department for inspection of equipment and premises, and a license shall be
issued by the Mayor to a qualifying applicant. 
(Ord. 35-89.  Passed 5-15-89.)
721.07  RECORDS AND REPORTS.
   (a)   The licensee shall maintain and have available at all times for
inspection by authorized Village personnel, detailed records covering all the
services rendered relative to this contract.
   (b)    Licensee shall at all times, maintain a ledger sheet, of all vehicles
towed and upon request must show it to any member of the Police Department.
Ledger sheets are to be made at the time of the tow, and information should be
recorded legibly, accurately and as completed as possible.
   (c)    The ledger sheet will contain all towed vehicles for the day. The
ledger sheet must include the following data:
      (1)    Name of owner or driver, if available.
      (2)    Make and model of vehicle.
      (3)    License number.
      (4)    Vehicle identification number.
      (5)    Time, date and location of tow.
      (6)    Circumstances of tow.
      (7)    Name of police officer requesting tow.
      (8)    Name of tow truck driver.
      (9)    Amount of charges.
      (10)    Date released and the person released to.
      (11)    Condition of vehicle.
         (Ord. 35-89. Passed 5-15-89.)
721.08  RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   (a)    The Chief of Police shall from time to time publish and distribute to
licensed towing firms or operators, and make available to applicants, rules and
regulations pertaining to licensed towing which shall include but not be
limited to procedures for towing and conditions of storage, additional required
equipment which should be carried on licensed vehicles to accomplish safe and
expeditious service and such other matters as would be in the best interest of
the public safety and welfare.
   (b)    Rules and regulations shall be approved by the Mayor and any
additions, deletions or corrections shall first be approved by the Mayor before
becoming effective.
(Ord. 35-89. Passed 5-15-89.)
721.09  REVOCATION OR SUSPENSION OF LICENSE.
   (a)    The Mayor may suspend a license of an operator who at any time fails
to be in compliance with sections of this chapter. A license shall be restored
upon return to compliance.
   (b)    The Mayor may revoke a license for failure to comply with sections of
this chapter or for a serious violation of the rules and regulations of this
chapter.
   (c)    Satisfactory proof that the tow truck owner has failed to resolve
complaints involving parts or property taken from an impounded vehicle or
damage to an impounded vehicle when such complaints are substantiated by
information contained in forms promulgated by the Chief of Police.
(Ord. 35-89. Passed 5-15-89.)
721.10  APPEAL.
   In the event that a license is revoked or suspended by the Mayor, the
licensee shall have the right to appeal such decision to Council. Council by a
majority vote may affirm, reverse or modify the order of the Mayor and their
decision shall be final and binding. Any appeal should be within ten working
days of the order of the Mayor and a decision rendered within ten days of a
hearing.
(Ord. 35-89. Passed 5-15-89.)
721.11  LICENSE TERM AND RENEWAL.
   (a)    A license granted under the provisions of this chapter shall be valid
for a period of one year from date of issue.
   (b)    A license must be renewed each year before the date of expiration
upon the same terms and conditions required for the issuance of a license as
contained in this chapter and a renewal fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00)
shall accompany the application.
(Ord. 35-89. Passed 5-15-89.)
721.12  DISTRIBUTION IF TOWING SERVICES AMONG LICENSEES.
   At any time that there is more than one qualified towing operator or towing
firm licensed, the Mayor shall issue an appropriate directive so that the
service shall be evenly distributed among the licensees as far as practicable
under any given circumstances.
(Ord. 35-89. Passed 5- 15-89.)
721.13  SERVICE CALL CANCELLATION.
   (a)    The Police Department has the right to cancel a request for towing
services until the time that a called wrecker is hooked onto a vehicle and has
completed the process of a hook up. At this stage the tow may be cancelled by
the police officer, but a service fee may be charged by the towing company.
   (b)    Hook up will consist of any of the following:
      (1)   Connecting chains and/or boom to vehicle and raising wheels off the
ground.
      (2)   Disconnecting transmission shift lever in order to put vehicle in
neutral.
         (Ord. 35-89. Passed 5-15-89.)
721.14  EQUIPMENT REQUIREMENTS.
   (a)    One rear view mirror on each side.
   (b)    One amber emergency flashing light visible from all sides, capable of
being seen for at least 500 feet, to be operated at the tow scene or while
actually towing vehicle, and one work light situated so as to illuminate the
winching or craining operations at night.
   (c)    Vehicle must meet all other requirements of State law and Municipal
ordinances.
   (d)    Towing vehicles must carry the following additional equipment:
      (1)    One set dolly wheels.
      (2)    One eight foot pick up chain.
      (3)    Safety chains.
      (4)   One broom and shovel.
      (5)    One all purpose fire extinguisher, maintained in operable
condition.
      (6)    A minimum of three thirty minute flares.
      (7)    Radio or cellular phone capable of communication with base.
      (8)    One snatch block.
      (9)    Hand tools (screwdriver, pliers, wire cutters).
      (10)    Adequate rope, line to secure loose parts and/or to secure
steering wheel.
      (11)    Reflective triangles.
         (Ord. 35-89. Passed 5-15-89.)
CHAPTER 731
Adult Entertainment Establishments
731.01   Definitions.
731.02   Licensing procedure.
731.03   Location and restrictions.
731.04   License fee; transfer and display.
731.05   Contents of license.
731.06   Regulations.
731.07   Revocation of license, hearing procedure.
731.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Obscenity offenses - see GEN. OFF. Ch.
533
 
731.01  DEFINITIONS.
   (a)   "Exhibitor" means any person or their agent, owning, exhibiting,
contracting for or permitting any electronically or mechanically operated
device as defined in this section to be installed, used or operated in his/her
place of business irrespective of the ownership of such device;
 
   (b)   "Electronically or mechanically operated device" means a machine
which, upon the insertion or acceptance of a coin, slug, or paper currency or
other medium, operates or may be operated for viewing images of a pornographic
or obscene nature;
 
   (c)   "Adult book store" means any commercial establishment in which one of
the primary functions is the sale or offering for sale or the rental of any
material, book or publication, photographs, film or other medium that offers
for viewing or permits the viewing of such medium which depicts nudity, sex,
the use of children, animals or other pornographic or obscene material;
 
   (d)   "Adult theater or adult movie house" means any theater or other
establishment which shows films rated X, NX-17 or any movie theater or adult
theater which presents for public viewing adult films or adult performances or
depicts for viewing the use of adults with children or any combination thereof
or adults or children with animals or combination thereof depicting nudity,
excretion or sexual conduct;
 
   (e)   "Commercial establishment" means any building which is designed to
permit public viewing of film or other medium which depicts nudity, sexual
conduct, excretion or use of animals by way of video units, mechanical or
electrically operated and accepting coins, slugs, paper currency or other
medium to operate it;
 
   (f)   "Owner" means any person having title, right of ownership, and/or
possession of any such mechanical or electrically operated machines which
depict pornographic or obscene material and/or the owner's agent;
 
   (g)   "Pornographic and/or obscene" means that material which appeals to the
prurient interest and which has a tendency to excite lustful thoughts.  Further
being such material which is patently offensive to the prevailing or
contemporary standards of the adult community in Lordstown;
 
   (h)   "Minor" is that person who is below the age of majority as currently
defined by the Legislature of the State of Ohio.
(Ord. 61-92.  Passed 9-8-92.)
731.02  LICENSING PROCEDURE.
   (a)   No exhibitor, owner or their agent shall operate or permit
electronically or mechanically operated devices, as defined in this chapter,
within the Village of Lordstown without first obtaining a license co-signed by
the Mayor and the Zoning Inspector.  Every exhibitor or owner shall make an
application in writing to the Mayor, which shall set forth:
      (1)   The name under which the business is to be conducted;
      (2)   The location where the business is to be carried on;
      (3)   The name and address of any manager, adult supervisor; or other
employee;
      (4)   The name and address of the owner or owners of the coin/currency
operated devices; and
      (5)   The name, address and principal occupation of every person with an
interest in the business.  If the business is conducted by:
         A.   A sole proprietorship, the name, and address and principal
occupation of that individual.
         B.   An unincorporated association, the names, addresses and principal
occupation of each officer.
         C.   A corporation, the names and addresses and principal occupation
of all officers.
 
   (b)   The Mayor and Zoning Inspector shall not issue a license to any
person, partnership, corporation or other entity if any of the persons with an
interest in the business have been convicted of a violation of a Federal or
State statute or of any local ordinance pertaining to gambling or other crime
of moral turpitude within five years preceding the application.
   Also, as a prerequisite to the issuance of such license, an inspection shall
be made of the premises by the County Building Inspector, the Village Fire
Department, and the County Board of Health, and approval must be had from each
of such agencies.
(Ord. 61-92.  Passed 9-8-92.)
731.03  LOCATION AND RESTRICTIONS.
   (a)   License shall be granted to an exhibitor only in a B-2 Zoning
District.
 
   (b)   No license shall be granted to an exhibitor that will conduct its
business at a location that is within 1,000 feet from the boundaries and/or a
parcel of real estate having situated on it a school, public library, public
playground, church, or public governmental building.
 
   (c)   No one twenty-one years or younger shall be employed or be permitted
to work in such adult book store, adult movie theater or other commercial
establishment as defined in this chapter.
 
   (d)   No one twenty-one years or younger shall enter or be permitted to
enter such adult book store, adult movie theater or other commercial
establishment as defined in this chapter.
(Ord. 61-92.  Passed 9-8-92.)
731.04  LICENSE FEE; TRANSFER AND DISPLAY.
   (a)   The annual license fee payable to the Village of Lordstown shall be
renewable by December 31 of each year and shall be as follows:
      (1)   The sum of one thousand five hundred dollars ($1,500) for each
device as defined in this chapter for the year or any part thereof ending on
December 31 of each year.
      (2)   This fee, which shall be paid at the time of application, is not
refundable in any case.
 
   (b)   Licenses issued under this section shall not be transferrable to any
other person, partnership, corporation, or other entity and the business may be
conducted only at the site for which the license is issued.  The license must
be placed as to be made conspicuously visible.
 
   (c)   Any person who does not comply with this chapter, in addition to other
penalties established, shall not be permitted to apply or reapply for a license
for a period of 365 days from the date a violation of this chapter is
discovered.
(Ord. 61-92.  Passed 9-8-92.)
731.05  CONTENTS OF LICENSE
   Upon approval of the application required by this section, the Mayor and
Zoning Inspector shall issue a license and registration which shall contain the
name and address of the licensee, the number of mechanically or electrically
operated devices exhibited, the address at which it is desired to exhibit and
operate the device, the nature of the business conducted at such place, the
make, name, model and other identifying information with reference to each
particular device to be exhibited, the serial number of the license, and other
such information as the Mayor in his discretion, may require.
(Ord. 61-92.  Passed 9-8-92.)
731.06  REGULATIONS.
   The Mayor is authorized and empowered to establish, adopt, and enforce, or
cause to be enforced such rules and regulations governing the issuance of the
licenses required under his chapter as he may deem reasonable and necessary and
not inconsistent with the provisions of this chapter.  Such regulations shall
be on file in the Mayor's office.
(Ord. 61-92.  Passed 9-8-92.)
731.07  REVOCATION OF LICENSE, HEARING PROCEDURE.
   The license may be suspended or revoked at any time by the Zoning Inspector
on satisfactory proof that violation of the laws of the State, ordinances of
the Village, rules and regulations of this chapter occur on the premises.  Such
Hearing Procedure shall be on file in the Mayor's office.
(Ord. 61-92.  Passed 9-8-92.)
731.99  PENALTY.
   Any person who offers for use or has on his premises one or more
electroncially or mechanically operated video viewing units displaying
pornographic or obscene material for use for which a license has not been
obtained and/or any violation of regulations set herein, shall be subject to
all other permits or licenses being revoked.
(Ord. 61-92.  Passed 9-8-92.)
CHAPTER 741
Solid Waste Collection and Disposal
741.01   Definitions.
741.02   Collection and disposal of solid waste from residential dwellings.
741.021   Prohibition on collection and disposal of solid waste from
residential dwellings.
741.022   Penalty.
741.03   Permit to collect and dispose of solid waste from trailer parks,
apartment complexes,  condominiums, and all non-residential operations.
741.04   Disposal of solid waste.
741.05   Additional rules and regulations to be adopted.
741.06   Permit revocation.
741.07   Vehicles transporting solid waste.
741.08   Scavenging prohibited.
741.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Collection and disposal of garbage - see Ohio R.C. 715.43, 717.01
Nuisances - see Ohio R.C. Chapter 3767
Disposal and transportation upon public ways - see Ohio R. C. 3767.20 et seq.
 
741.01  DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter, the following words shall have the meanings
ascribed to them
in this section.
   (a)   Apartment Building Complex - A residential structure consisting of two
or  more single residential units.
   (b)   Bags - Plastic sacks designed to store refuse with sufficient wall
strength to maintain physical integrity when lifted by top. Total weight of a
bag and its contents not to exceed 35 pounds.
   (c)   Board of Public Affairs (BPA) or Village BPA - Board of Trustees of
Public Affairs of the Village of Lordstown.
   (d)   Bulky Waste - Stoves, refrigerators, air conditioners, water tanks,
washing machines, furniture and other bulky waste materials other than
construction debris or dead animals, with weights or volumes greater than those
allowed for containers or bags.
   (e)   Bundle - Tree, shrub and brush trimmings or newspapers and magazines
securely tied together forming an easily handled package not exceeding three
(3) feet in length or 35 pounds in weight.
   (f)   Commercial/Retail Size Dumpster - A container for storing solid waste
which exceeds 96 gallons; generally consists of steel floor, walls, and lids
and set on four wheels.
   (g)   Condominium Complex - A residential development consisting of two or
more single residential units within the same allotment; structures may be
adjoining or in a cluster format.
   (h)   Construction Debris - Waste building materials resulting from
construction, remodeling, repair or demolition operations. Debris shall be tied
into bundles not longer than three (3) feet in length or 35 pounds in weight.
   (i)   Containers - A receptacle with the capacity up to 35 to 40 gallons,
constructed of plastic, metal or fiberglass, having handles of adequate
strength for lifting and having a tight fitting lid capable of preventing
entrance into the container by vectors. The maximum allowable weight to be
placed on each container is 50 pounds. The mouth of the container shall have a
diameter greater than or equal to that of the base. The Contractor may offer
each resident larger containers up to 96 gallons for an additional cost charged
only to those residents who select this additional service.
   (j)   Contractor - The person, corporation or partnership performing refuse
collection and disposal under contract with the Village.
   (k)   Dead Animals - Small domestic animals, weighing no more than 30 pounds
that have expired from any cause.
   (l)   Disposal Site - A refuse depository including but not limited to
sanitary landfills, transfer stations, incinerators, and waste processing/
separation centers licensed, permitted or approved to receive for processing of
final disposal of residential solid waste (including dead animals) by all
governmental bodies and agencies having jurisdiction and requiring such
licenses, permits or approvals.
   (m)   Garbage - Any and all dead animals except those slaughtered for human
consumption; every accumulation of waste (animal, vegetable and/or other
matter) that results from the preparation, processing, consumption, dealing in,
handling, packing, canning, storage, transportation, decay or decomposition of
meats, fish, fowl, birds, fruits, grains, or other animal or vegetable matter
(including, but not by way of limitation, used tin cans and other food
containers; and all putrescible or easily decomposable waste animal or
vegetable matter which is likely to attract flies or rodents); except (in all
cases) any matter included in the definition of bulky waste, construction
debris, hazardous waste, or rubbish.
   (n)   Hazardous Waste - Any chemical, compound mixture, substance or article
which is designated by the United States to be "hazardous" as that term is
defined by or pursuant to Federal or State Law.
   (o)   Producer - An occupant of a residential unit who generates refuse.
   (p)   Project Manager - The key contact person at the private company
providing solid waste collection services.
   (q)   Recyclable Materials - For the purpose of this document, recyclable
materials will include newspapers (including advertisement and magazines),
glass bottles, glass jars, aluminum beverage containers, bi-metal containers,
HDPE #1, HDPE #2, chipboard and corrugated cardboard.
   (r)   Residential Refuse - All garbage and rubbish generated by a producer
at a residential unit.
   (s)   Residential Solid Waste - Residential refuse, bulky waste, and
construction debris generated at a residential unit.
   (t)   Residential Unit - A dwelling within the corporate limits of the
Village occupied by a person or group of persons comprising not more than four
families. A residential unit shall be deemed occupied when either water or
domestic light and power services are being supplied thereto. A condominium
dwelling, whether of single or multi-level construction consisting of four or
less contiguous or separate single-family dwelling units, shall be treated as a
residential unit, except that each single-family dwelling within any such
residential unit shall be billed separately as a residential unit.
   (u)   Rubbish - All waste wood products, tree, shrub and brush trimmings,
grass cuttings, dead plants, weeds, leaves, dead trees, or branches thereof,
chips, shavings, sawdust, printed matter, pasteboard, rags, straw, used and
discarded clothing, used and discarded shoes and boots, combustible waste pulp
and other products such as are used for packaging, or wrapping crockery and
glass, ashes, cinders, floor sweepings, glass, mineral or metallic substances,
and any and all other waste materials not included in the definition of bulky
waste, construction debris, garbage or hazardous waste.
   (v)   Trailer Park - A residential development consisting of mobile home
units within an allotment.
   (w)   Type of Service - The level of solid waste collection and disposal
generally consisting of the choice between pick-up at the curb and front door
and whether to use containers versus pre-paid bags.
   (x)   Village - Village of Lordstown, Ohio.
      (Ord. 52-2008.  Passed 6-16-08.)
741.02  COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL OF SOLID WASTE FROM RESIDENTIAL DWELLINGS.
   The Village, through its duly-authorized employees or agents or other
Village- authorized corporations, entities, or firms, shall collect and/or
remove garbage and rubbish from all residential dwelling units as hereinafter
provided:
   (a)   The method or procedure to be followed for the collection of garbage
and rubbish shall be determined by the Board of Public Affairs.
   (b)   The type, placement, and services provided for garbage and rubbish
containers shall be established by the Board of Public Affairs.
      (Ord. 52-2008.  Passed 6-16-08.)
741.021 PROHIBITION ON COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL OF SOLID WASTE FROM RESIDENTIAL
DWELLINGS.
   No person or firm, other than the duly-authorized employees or agents of the
Village or other Village authorized corporation, entities, or firms, shall
collect or remove any garbage or rubbish within the Village except recyclable
materials or convey or transport same over or upon any street or public highway
therein, except as hereinafter provided.
(Ord. 52-2008.  Passed 6-16-08.)
741.022 PENALTY.
   (a)   The Board of Public Affairs or its designee; Village Planning and
Zoning Administrator, or his designee; or any law enforcement officer for the
Village of Lordstown shall enforce all provisions of Section
741.02  of the Codified Ordinances of the Village of Lordstown and any rules,
ordinances, laws or regulations prescribed pursuant thereto.
   (b)   Whoever violates any of the provisions of Section
741.02  of the Codified Ordinances of the Village of Lordstown or any orders,
rules, or regulators of the Board of Public Affairs, or his designee, or
Village Planning and Zoning Administrator, or his designee, made pursuant to
Section
741.02 , is guilty of a minor misdemeanor and shall be issued a littering
citation. Each day's continued violation shall constitute a separate offense.
(Ord. 52-2008.  Passed 6-16-08.)
741.03  PERMIT TO COLLECT AND DISPOSE OF SOLID WASTE FROM TRAILER PARKS,
APARTMENT COMPLEXES, CONDOMINIUMS, AND ALL NON-RESIDENTIAL OPERATIONS.
   No person shall collect or remove solid waste within the Village, or convey
or transport the same over or upon any street or public highway therein, until
and unless a permit therefore has been issued by the Board of Public Affairs. A
schedule of permit fees and insurance requirements shall be kept on file with
the Clerk of the Board of Public Affairs.
(Ord. 52-2008.  Passed 6-16-08.)
741.04  DISPOSAL OF SOLID WASTE.
   No person, other than the duly authorized employees of the Village, shall
dispose of any solid waste in the Village collected from any source or by any
means whatsoever, except upon premises or other facilities owned, used or
provided therefore by the Village. Before so doing, a permit therefore shall be
obtained from the Board of Public Affairs.
(Ord. 52-2008.  Passed 6-16-08.)
741.05  ADDITIONAL RULES AND REGULATIONS TO BE ADOPTED.
   The Board of Public Affairs shall make and enforce such additional orders,
rules and regulations as may be necessary to the proper collection and disposal
of solid waste and the use of disposal facilities owned, used or provided
therefore by the Village.
(Ord. 52-2008.  Passed 6-16-08.)
741.06  PERMIT REVOCATION.
   Any permit issued under this chapter shall be issued subject to revocation
or termination at any time upon written notice personally delivered to the
permittee or mailed by registered mail to his address given at the time of
application therefore. Violation of any order, rule or regulation, or
curtailment of use of such premises or facilities by the Village, shall be
deemed conclusive cause for termination or revocation of such permit.
(Ord. 52-2008.  Passed 6-16-08.)
741.07  VEHICLES TRANSPORTING SOLID WASTE.
   No person shall operate or cause to be operated with the Village, a vehicle
transporting any of the materials defined in Section
741.01 , whether the same is accumulated or originated within or without the
Village, unless such vehicle is so constructed as to completely enclose the
load. Open bodied dump trucks or other similar vehicles shall be covered by a
tarpaulin or other protective covering sufficient to prevent any of its load
from dropping, falling or otherwise escaping therefrom. 
(Ord. 52-2008.  Passed 6-16-08.)
741.08  SCAVENGING PROHIBITED.
   No person shall remove, burn, overturn or tamper with any solid waste or the
container therefore, when such solid waste or container is set out on the
public street or highway, sidewalk, alley or on private premises and when such
solid waste or container is placed there for the purpose of collection. This
provision shall not apply to any employee of the Village or any of its duly
authorized agents or any State, Local or Federal police agency or to a private
person or organization authorized to remove such solid waste or container.
(Ord. 52-2008.  Passed 6-16-08.)
741.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any of the provisions of this chapter or any order, rule or
regulation of the Board of Public Affairs, or their designate, made pursuant to
this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor of the first degree, and each
day's continued violation shall constitute a separate offense.
(Ord. 52-2008.  Passed 6-16-08.)

901.01  RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   The following rules and regulations, including standards and requirements
for street and plat improvements and developments in Lordstown, under the
supervision of the Street Commissioner and Council, be and the same are herein
adopted:
(a)    The developers shall submit full construction drawings and arrange for 
preconstruction conferences with the Street Commissioner and the appropriate
committee of Council before the commencement of work.
(b)    All preliminary drainage and /or permanent drainage construction shall
be provided for and completed prior to the actual construction of any road or
street.
(c)    All drainage ditches shall be to final grade before installation of
pipe.
(d)    All construction drawings shall clearly indicate subgrade and final
grade elevations together with offset stakes.
(e)    The excavations for utility lines (water, gas, electric, telephone,
cable, oil and storm and sanitary sewers) within the roadway or the crossing of
any right of way shall be tamped with acceptable compactor to subgrade.
(f)    All soft or unacceptable areas or sections in the subgrade of any street
or road in the process of improvement shall be removed and replaced with
material of a quality that meets with the approval of the Street Commissioner.
(g)    Any and all materials used in the development of plats or in the
improvement on streets already accepted shall be in accordance with and follow
the requirements of the State specifications or the equivalent thereof.
   (h)   Any construction involving a street opening or curb cut shall require
a “Street Opening/Curb Cut” permit.  (See:  Chapter
1177 Planning and Zoning Code.)
      (Ord. 93-2006.  Passed 12-28-06.)
901.02  COMPLIANCE.
   The Street Commissioner is herein granted full authority to halt any project
plat or development where the construction or improvements therein are not in
accordance with the plans and specifications and rules and regulations
contained herein or where such performance is not in accordance with the
preconstruction guidelines.
(Ord. 16-79. Passed 2-20-79.)
901.99  PENALTY .
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be guilty of a minor
misdemeanor and shall be fined not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00).
Each day a violation continues or occurs shall constitute a separate offense.

Excavations

521.03
911.01  REGISTRATION REQUIRED.
   No person, firm, company, including Trumbull County, or corporation shall
engage in the business of contracting for services to be rendered, in part or
in full, for any work in connection with any excavation in the public right of
way of any street, avenue, road, drive, lane or any other public grounds for
the purposes of installing, repairing, or cleaning of any sanitary sewer, storm
sewer, sanitary lateral, storm connection, underground low voltage cable and
the installation, repair, and replacement of sidewalk, driveway, curbing and
any other type of excavation without first registering with the Village as a
Utility Contractor.
(Ord. 62-2008.  Passed 7-16-08.)
911.02  PERMIT REQUIRED.
   (a)    No person, firm, company, including Trumbull County, or corporation
shall engage in the business of contracting for services to be rendered, in
part or in full, for any work in connection with any excavation in the public
right of way of any street, avenue, road, drive, lane or any other public
grounds for the purposes of installing, repairing, replacing or cleaning of any
sanitary sewer, storm sewer, sanitary lateral, storm connection, underground
low voltage cable, water line, water connection, gas line, gas connection,
underground electric line and/or service and the installation, repair and
replacement of sidewalk, driveway, curbing and any other type of excavation
without first obtaining a permit.
   (b)    Public utility companies are exempt from the provisions of this
section except for: new or replacement underground construction. Two (2) sets
of plans of any proposed new or replacement underground construction must be
submitted to the Village for approval by the Engineer prior to installation.
Submitted plans shall be drawn to scale and show at a minimum the right of way,
street or curb line, existing underground utilities, depth of installation,
street name, north arrow, the submitter's name, address and telephone number
and all existing topography, such as driveways, sidewalk, hydrants, trees, etc.
   (c)    Permits may be issued to single family property owners, occupying the
home where the work is to commence, without being registered, desiring to
install downspout drains or ditch/drainage pipes between the right of way line,
edge of pavement, curb or road ditch, provided that no connection is made in
the storm sewer. Before a permit shall be issued, the property owner shall sign
a waiver, as approved by the Village, stating the property owner is actually
doing the work and holding the Village harmless from all suits and claims
arising from such work or installation.
   (d)    All existing gas lines, waterlines, sanitary sewer lines or storm
sewers to be replaced shall, once the new installation is complete, be
completely removed and disposed of by the Contractor. No existing facilities
shall be permitted to be abandoned and remain within any public right-of-way of
any street, avenue, road, drive, lane or any other public grounds in the
Village of Lordstown. 
(Ord. 62-2008.  Passed 7-16-08.)
911.03  FEES REQUIRED.
   No person, firm, corporation or company shall be issued a permit until the
fee required by and prescribed in the Codified Ordinances of the Village of
Lordstown, Ohio, has been paid, nor shall any amendment to a permit be approved
until the additional fee, if any, due to the amendment has been paid.
The fees for work in the right of way are as follows:
 
All excavations and permitted work:    $25.00
   Except sanitary sewer mains, water and
   sanitary sewer service connections

               Section 100.2 of Chapter 100
               ("Sewer Regulations"); or as set
               forth in Board of Public Affairs
               Resolution

               accordance with Board of Public
               Affairs Resolution Nos. 1-87 and
               1-88.
Sanitary sewer connections:      $25.00, plus any fees set forth in
               Section 100.3 of Chapter 100
               ("Sewer Regulations"); or as set
               forth in Board of Public Affairs
               Resolution.
Public utilities:         $1.00 per linear foot; $2,000
               minimum
All re-inspection fees         $50.00 per hour; $100 minimum
(Ord. 62-2008.  Passed 7-16-08.)
911.04  REVOCATION; PERMIT.
   A permit may be revoked at any time upon a determination by the Village of
the contractor using non-specified materials, or for faulty workmanship, or for
failure to follow the plans, or the failure to follow the line and grade as
instructed or as indicated on the plans.
(Ord. 62-2008.  Passed 7-16-08.)
911.05  BACKFILL AND REPAIR OF PAVEMENTS.
   (a)    All persons taking out permits to excavate within the street limits
or public places of the Village shall notify, forty-eight (48) hours in
advance, the Utilities Protection Service and/or all utilities before
commencing actual work and such utility companies shall furnish information
necessary for the protection of their installations.
   (b)    The permit holder shall take all necessary working precautions and be
responsible for any damage to existing utilities, such as sewers, sewer
laterals, gas lines, water lines, electrical conduits, poles, railroad tracks,
fences, buildings or other structures and facilities adjacent to the work,
unless it can be proven that such damage was caused by faulty information,
materials, and maintenance provided by the utility company involved. All
repairs shall be made to the satisfaction of the Village.
   (c)    All underground utilities uncovered during the progress of the work
shall be properly shored, and the work shall be conducted so as not to
interfere with the operation of such utilities or endanger the operation of
such utilities, without consent of the owners thereof.
   (d)    The permit holder shall further be responsible for maintaining the
normal drainage with temporary structures and to maintain traffic, unless a
permit is granted by the Street Commissioner to close such area to traffic.
Every excavation or opening shall be guarded by barricades twenty-four (24)
hours per day and shall be lighted during the time from sunset to sunrise with
two or more lights. The permit holder shall save the Village harmless from any
and all damages to persons and property resulting from such excavation or
opening or from want of reasonable diligence and care.
   (e)    The permit holder shall comply with the following backfill
requirements for all installations under the streets, roads, and highways
within the Village. These requirements also apply to all installations under
driveways, parking lots, and other paved or aggregate surfaces.
      (1)   Prior to placing the conduit or utility into the trench, six inches
of natural aggregate shall be placed in the bottom of the trench to serve as
bedding.
      (2)    After placement of the utility, natural aggregate shall be placed
evenly around the conduit and filled to a level 12 inches above the top of
pipe.
      (3)    Natural aggregates described in subparagraph (e) (1) above shall
consist of No. 57 limestone.
      (4)    The remaining trench envelope between the natural aggregate and
the bottom of pavement shall consist of low strength mortar.
      (5)    Pavement restoration shall match the composition and thickness of
the existing pavement, but shall not be less than the following:
 
asphalt pavement      1 1/4 inches ODOT 448 Surface
            1 3/4 inches ODOT 448 Intermediate
            6 inches ODOT 301
concrete pavement      6 inches Class C Concrete
aggregate roads, drives,
    parking lots      6 inches ODOT 304
            (limestone only)
   (f)    For installations in lawn areas, the permit holder shall comply with
items (1) through (3) of subsection (e) for all sanitary sewers, water main,
and storm sewers. The remainder of the trench for these utilities may be
backfilled with in-situ material and finished with four inches of top soil with
seeding and mulch. All other utilities shall comply with backfill requirements
acceptable to the utility provider. The top of these utility trenches shall
also be restored with top soil, seeding, and mulch.
   (g)    The permit holder shall be responsible to check and maintain
excavations to grade until a final surface is made. If the permit holder fails
to properly maintain the work, the Village has the right to take whatever
action is necessary to protect the public and invoice the permit holder for all
costs associated with this action.
(Ord. 62-2008.  Passed 7-16-08.)
911.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be fined not more than
two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) for each offense. An offense shall be
deemed to have occurred for each twenty-four (24) hour period that lapses from
initial violation.
(Ord. 62-2008.  Passed 7-16-08.)

CROSS REFERENCES

925.01  SANITARY SEWER TAP-INS TO PROPERTIES ABUTTING THE CONSTRUCTION OF A
SANITARY SEWER LINE.
   (a)   The village owns, operates, and manages sanitary sewers in its East
Side Sanitary Sewer District.  Refer to the Sanitary Sewer Rules and
Regulations on file at the Water Clerk’s Office at the Village Administration
Building.  These sanitary sewer rules and regulations contain a map
illustrating the boundary of the East Side Sanitary Sewer District.  For all
other sanitary sewers in the Village, refer to Trumbull County Sanitary
Engineers.
   (b)   The Village constructs sanitary sewer lines abutting property owned by
residents within the Village.
   (c)   The Village believes that it is desirable to establish a uniform
policy governing when the Village shall permit property owners to tap into a
sanitary sewer line abutting their property and to establish a policy for the
sharing of costs for such tap in.
   (d)   The following policy which has been recommended by C T Consultants,
Inc., shall become the uniform policy governing sanitary sewer “tap-ins” within
the Village of Lordstown:
      (1)   Properties having a dwelling located on the property at the time
the sewer line is being installed abutting said property shall receive one tap
per dwelling.  A tap shall consist of a saddle over the sewer main and an
extension pipe extending from the sewer line to the edge of the road right of
way on the side of the road where the dwelling is situated.  Costs for such tap
shall be borne by the Village and charged to Village Capital Improvements Fund.
      (2)   Properties without a dwelling shall not receive a tap unless
arrangements have been made previous to installation of the sewer main.  Cost
of such tap will be at the property owner’s expense and paid for by the
property owner before installation of such tap.
      (3)   In both cases, it shall be the property owner’s responsibility to
provide and pay for the service sewer connection from the tap to the dwelling.
      (4)   Sewer taps installed after the sewer line has been installed shall
be at the property owner’s expense, but must be completed per governing
sanitary sewer rules and regulations.
         (Ord. 53-2018.  Passed 9-17-18.)

   and Holidays               $400.00
 
(d)   Cost of Cremations and Openings and Closing Stillborn Graves.
   (1)   Burial of cremains and opening and closing stillborn
      graves between 8:00 a.m. and 2:00 p.m. Monday

      Saturday, Sunday, and Holidays      $250.00

   (f)   Use of Cemetery Chapel.  A Chapel is located at the Salt Springs Road
Cemetery, and is available at no charge for all funerals at this Cemetery.  The
funeral director shall be responsible for notifying the Village that the Chapel
is requested.  In the event of conflicting funeral services, use of the Chapel
will be granted on a “first to request basis.”
(Ord. 33-2017.  Passed 6-12-17.)
941.03  CEMETERY RULES.
   (a)   Determination of lot, section, and grave for all burials is the
responsibility of the funeral director of the deceased.  The Village shall be
given this information when notified of a burial.
   (b)   All Village of Lordstown Cemeteries are open from sunrise to sunset
daily. No person(s) shall enter any Cemetery after sunset or before sunrise.
   (c)   Flowers and perennials may be planted near monuments, however, they
must be regularly weeded and maintained by the owners.  Plantings must be edged
or bordered in order for Village employees to properly trim around.  Plantings,
ornaments, and decorations must be kept in a sensible area around monuments so
they do not impede equipment from performing normal cemetery duties (i.e.,
mowing, trimming, grave digging and dirt hauling).
   (d)   Shrubbery and bushes are not permitted to be planted on Cemetery lots.
   (e)   No trees will be planted without permission from the Parks
Superintendent and the Street Commissioner.  The species of the tree will be
determined by the Parks Superintendent and the Street Commissioner.
   (f)   All plantings not properly maintained by the owners will be removed.
   (g)   Grave ornamentation which is holiday or seasonal in nature shall be
removed in a timely manner after each holiday or season has passed.
   (h)   The Village Lordstown shall not be responsible for any Cemetery
ornamentation which is lost, stolen, damaged or removed.
(Ord. 33-2017.  Passed 6-12-17.)
941.04  REGULATIONS GOVERNING MONUMENTS AND MONUMENT FOUNDATIONS.
   (a)   All monument foundations shall be installed by the Village of
Lordstown.
   (b)   No monument foundation shall be installed on a grave site earlier than
six months after the opening and closing of that particular grave.
   (c)   Monument foundations and monuments may be installed pre-need.
   (d)   The Village of Lordstown shall not be responsible for incorrectly
engraved monuments.  Verification of the positioning of names on monuments is
the responsibility of the family and/or the monument vendor.
   (e)   Monument foundation size for a single grave shall not exceed 48 inches
in length, and 30 inches in width.  Monument foundation size to cover two
graves shall not exceed 108 inches in length, and 30 inches in width.
   Any other multiple grave monuments must be approved for size by the Parks
Superintendent and Street Commissioner.
   (f)   No monument foundations shall be installed after October 31st or
before May 1st.
   (g)   All monument foundations are installed with a two inch concrete border
on all sides.  Examples:  monument size 10" x 30" shall have a foundation size
16" x  36".
   (h)   All monuments shall be placed at the head of the graves (west end of
grave).  No foot markers above the ground will be permitted.
(Ord. 33-2017.  Passed 6-12-17.)
941.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be guilty of a minor
misdemeanor and shall be fined not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
Each day a violation continues or occurs shall constitute a separate offense.

945.01  NOXIOUS WEEDS AND GRASS TO BE CUT.
   (a)   Every owner, lessee, agent or tenant having charge of or
responsibility for the maintenance of the following described lots or lands
within the Village shall be required to cut noxious weeds, grass, brush,
briars, burrs, vines or other types of vegetation as hereinafter described:
      (1)   All lots in a recorded subdivision must be maintained as provided
in subsection (b) hereof in their entirety.
      (2)   All parcels of land containing a dwelling and/or public building
must be maintained, as provided in subsection (b) hereof along all roadway
frontage, up to a maximum of 200 feet, and for an area of 200 feet in depth
from the adjoining edge of any roadway.
 
   (b)   Every owner, lessee, agent or tenant having charge of or
responsibility for the maintenance of any lot or land described in this section
shall be required to cut all such weeds and vegetation, including, but not
limited to, Russian, Canadian or common thistle, wild parsley, ragweed,
milkweed, ironweed, as well as all other prohibited noxious weeds as designated
by the Ohio Director of Agriculture, brush, briars, burrs or vines and all
other types of vegetation growing or being upon the lots or lands as provided
in subsection (a) hereof to a height not to exceed ten inches.  Any growth of
such noxious weeds, grass, brush, briars, burrs, vines or other vegetation over
such height is hereby declared a nuisance.
(Ord. 10-95.  Passed 2-21-95.)
945.02  NOTICE TO OWNER TO CUT WEEDS AND GRASS.
   Upon complaint and determination by the Zoning Inspector that weeds on any
lands are, or are approaching such growth, as prohibited in this chapter,
notice thereof shall be sent to the owner of the subject property, provided
that the weeds must be cut within ten days from the receipt of said notice. 
Such notice shall be sent in accordance with Ohio R.C. 731.51 and 731.52, to
the owner, lessee, agent or tenant having charge of such lands.
(Ord. 10-95.  Passed 2-21-95.)
 
945.03  FAILURE TO COMPLY WITH NOTICE.
   Upon failure to comply with the notice in Section
945.02 hereof within the prescribed time to cut and destroy noxious weeds and
grass the Zoning Inspector shall immediately notify the Street Department of
the location of such lands and the Street Department shall forthwith cut and
destroy such weeds and grass.
(Ord. 8-87.  Passed 1-5-87.)
 
945.04  COSTS.
   (a)   The Street Department shall keep accurate record of the cost of such
cutting and shall immediately cause to be sent to the proper person as required
by Ohio R.C. 731.53 a statement for such cost of each cutting required during
the growing months which shall be immediately due and payable.
 
   (b)   The minimum fee to be charged shall in no case be less than one
hundred and five dollars ($105.00) for the first hour or portion thereof and
one hundred and five dollars ($105.00) for each additional hour or portion
thereof.
 
   (c)   A second notice of payment due may be sent not later than the first
day of October each year for the total cost of each and every cutting not paid,
which shall be immediately due and payable.
 
   (d)   All payments received shall be credited to the General Fund, but no
payment shall be accepted after the certification to the County Auditor as
hereinafter provided.
(Ord. 8-87.  Passed 1-5-87.)
 
945.05  CERTIFICATION TO COUNTY AUDITOR OF UNPAID COST FOR WEED CUTTING FOR
LIEN UPON PROPERTY.
   Not later than October 15 of each year the Zoning Inspector shall make a
written return to the County Auditor of its actions under this chapter and Ohio
R.C. 731.51 to 731.73 with a statement of the charges for its services, the
amount paid for the performing of such labor as certified by the Street
Department, the fees for officers who made the service and notice of return and
a proper description of the premises. The return to the County Auditor shall be
for the purpose of having such amounts entered upon the tax duplicate as a lien
upon such lands in accordance with the provisions of Ohio R.C. 731.54.
(Ord. 8-87.  Passed 1-5-87.)
 
945.06  EXCEPTIONS.
   The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to land within the Village
used exclusively for agricultural purposes.
(Ord. 8-87. Passed 1-5-87.)
945.99  PENALTY.
   It is hereby determined that the growth of noxious weeds upon lands within
the Village not only pose a harmful or injurious threat to the health or
physical wellbeing of the inhabitants of the Village but also pose a
significant safety hazard and that anyone who violates any section of this
chapter, in addition to the assessment of costs for failure to comply with
proper notice, shall be guilty of a minor misdemeanor.
(Ord. 8-87. Passed 1-5-87.)
 
CHAPTER 949
Use and Rental of Public Buildings
949.01   Scope.
949.02   Intoxicants restricted.
949.03   Obstructing traffic.
949.04   All-terrain vehicles, etc., prohibited.
949.05   Disturbing the peace.
949.06   Noise.
949.07   Weapons.
949.08   Littering.
949.09   Hours.
949.10   Vandalism.
949.11   Parking or driving vehicles.
949.12   Animals.
949.13   Return of park equipment.
949.14   Hunting; trapping.
949.15   Rollerskating; skateboards.
949.16   Shoes.
949.17   Tennis and basketball courts.
949.18   Concession stand.
949.19   Conflict.
949.20   Failure to obey order.
949.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Land appropriation for parks - see Ohio R.C. 715.21, 719.01
Playgrounds - see Ohio R.C. 755.12 et seq.
Power to regulate vehicle speed in parks - see Ohio R.C. 4511.07(E)
 
949.01  SCOPE.
   Effective January 1, 2010, the use and rental of Village Public Buildings,
i.e., Administration Building, Park Pavilions and Gazebo, and the rules and
regulations for such uses of such public buildings by the general public shall
be under the jurisdiction of the Superintendent of the Streets, Sidewalks,
Public Parks, Buildings, Grounds, and General Improvement (the "Street
Commissioner") and pursuant to the attached Exhibit "A" entitled "Rules and
Regulations" which is incorporated by reference as though fully rewritten
herein.
(Ord. 36-2017.  Passed 7-11-17.)
949.02  INTOXICANTS RESTRICTED.
   No consumption of alcoholic beverages or drugs shall be permitted on Village
property, including the roadways and parking lots located therein, except in
conjunction with Article 12 of the Rules and Regulations attached hereto.
(Ord. 36-2017.  Passed 7-11-17.)
949.03  OBSTRUCTING TRAFFIC.
   No person shall obstruct traffic on the roadways, access roads or parking
lot areas.
(Ord. 36-2017.  Passed 7-11-17.)
949.04  ALL-TERRAIN VEHICLES, ETC., PROHIBITED.
   No person shall operate a mini-bike, dirt bike, all-terrain vehicle or dune
buggy anywhere on Village property.
(Ord. 36-2017.  Passed 7-11-17.)
949.05  DISTURBING THE PEACE.
   No person shall disturb the peace in the parks.
(Ord. 36-2017.  Passed 7-11-17.)
949.06  NOISE.
   Excessively loud music and noise are prohibited and the use or playing of
musical instruments in the parks is permitted only for the enjoyment of the
individual using the instruments, and in so doing, the instrument must be
played in a manner that will not disturb or be offensive to other park
visitors.  The same regulations apply to radios, tape decks, stereos and record
players.
(Ord. 36-2017.  Passed 7-11-17.)
949.07  WEAPONS.
   No person shall carry within the parks, buildings, grounds or gazebo bows,
crossbows, longbows, or arrows, fireworks, explosives, sling shots of any kind,
nor discharge any of the same. That no person shall carry within the parks,
buildings, grounds or gazebo firearms or ammunition, unless otherwise allowed
by law. This section shall not apply to licensed fireworks operators under
contract with the Village of Lordstown.
(Ord. 36-2017.  Passed 7-11-17.)
949.08  LITTERING.
   No person shall discard or dump within the parks, buildings, playgrounds or
gazebo any paper, garbage, ashes, bottles, cans, refuse or foreign materials of
any description. Refuse, garbage, and other residue of a picnic or other
permitted activity shall be deposited in receptacles provided for such
purposes.
(Ord. 36-2017.  Passed 7-11-17.)
949.09  HOURS.
   Village parks shall be closed from 11:00 p.m. to 8:30 a.m. No person shall
park a vehicle within any park during the hours of darkness, except when park
facilities are being used in accordance with the regulations of the facility.
The Streets, Sidewalks, Public Parks, Buildings, Grounds and General
Improvement Department may close any drive or facility or cease any activity at
any time, where in the Department's judgment, acting through the Street
Commissioner, such drive, facility or activity is deemed unsafe or the best
interests, general well being and safety of the public is not being observed.
(Ord. 36-2017.  Passed 7-11-17.)
949.10  VANDALISM.
   No person shall in any way injure, deface, destroy, disturb or remove any
part of a building, equipment, sign or structure or any tree, flower, shrub,
plant or other vegetation.
(Ord. 36-2017.  Passed 7-11-17.)
949.11  PARKING OR DRIVING VEHICLES.
   Parking or driving of motor vehicles is permitted only in parking areas
provided for that purpose and is not permitted outside of the roadways, parking
lots and access roads.  No person shall park or stop a motor vehicle in areas
not designated for parking.
(Ord. 36-2017.  Passed 7-11-17.)
949.12  ANIMALS.
   All animals must be on a leash while on Village property.  The owners are
responsible for cleaning up after their pet.
(Ord. 36-2017.  Passed 7-11-17.)
949.13  RETURN OF PARK EQUIPMENT.
   Any person using park recreational equipment must pick up and return it by
the time designated by the Street Commissioner.
(Ord. 36-2017.  Passed 7-11-17.)
949.14  HUNTING; TRAPPING.
   No hunting or trapping is permitted on park property.
(Ord. 36-2017.  Passed 7-11-17.)
949.15  ROLLERSKATING; SKATEBOARDS.
   No person shall roller skate or skate board on the tennis courts or
basketball courts of the Village parks.
(Ord. 36-2017.  Passed 7-11-17.)
949.16  SHOES.
   No person shall wear any type of shoes with metal spikes on any paved
surface of Village parks or grounds (such as walks, tennis courts, basketball
courts).
(Ord. 36-2017.  Passed 7-11-17.)
949.17  TENNIS AND BASKETBALL COURTS.
   Tennis courts and basketball courts will officially open from the first
Monday of April and remain open as long as weather permits (as determined by
the Street Commissioner).  Lighting for said courts will be provided beginning
the first Monday of June and continue until the third Friday in September.
(Ord. 36-2017.  Passed 7-11-17.)
949.18  CONCESSION STAND.
   A concession stand is available for rental at an additional fee of one
hundred dollars ($100.00) per day.  The renter is responsible for any equipment
damage during use and is responsible for cleaning up when done.
(Ord. 36-2017.  Passed 7-11-17.)
949.19  CONFLICT.
   Park visitors are subject to state and federal law and local ordinances. 
Federal, state and local ordinances shall prevail when and if these rules and
regulations conflict therewith.
(Ord. 36-2017.  Passed 7-11-17.)
949.20  FAILURE TO OBEY ORDER.
   No person shall refuse to comply with any reasonable order of any police
officer, park official or employee relating to any specific facility or these
general rules and regulations.  No person shall willfully resist, obstruct or
abuse any police officer, park official or employee in the execution of his/her
duty.
(Ord. 36-2017.  Passed 7-11-17.)
949.99  PENALTY.
   Violators of any of these rules and regulations are subject to suspension of
park and building privileges for a period of time to be determined by the
Street Commissioner, Mayor, and Police Chief.  Violations must make restitution
for any and all damages.
(Ord. 36-2017.  Passed 7-11-17.)

   CODIFIED ORDINANCES OF LORDSTOWN
   PART ELEVEN - PLANNING AND ZONING CODE

CHAPTER 1101
Title, Scope and Jurisdiction
1101.00   Title.
1101.01   Policy.
1101.02   Purpose.
1101.03   Authority.
1101.04   Jurisdiction and applicability.
1101.05   Relation to other laws.
1101.06   Validity and separability.
1101.07   Saving provision.
1101.08   Enactment.
 
1101.00  TITLE.
   These rules, regulations and standards shall be officially known as the
“Subdivision Regulations of the Village of Lordstown, Ohio,” and shall
hereinafter be referred to as “these Regulations.” 
(Ord. 56-2005.  Passed 10-3-05.)
1101.01  POLICY.
   (a)   It is declared to be the policy of the Village of Lordstown to
consider the subdivision of land and its subsequent development as subject to
the control of the Village of Lordstown,  pursuant to these Regulations in
order to promote and protect the public health, safety and general welfare and
to provide procedures by which these Regulations are administered to ensure the
orderly, planned, efficient, and economical development of the Village.
   (b)   Land to be subdivided shall be of such character that it can be used
safely for building purposes without danger to health or peril from fire, flood
or other menace, and shall not be subdivided until such time as adequate public
facilities and improvements exist, and proper provisions have been made for
storm water management, water supply, treatment of sewerage, and other public
improvements and services are provided, or a performance bond is filed to
assure that the required improvements will be made by the subdivider.
   (c)   Land to be subdivided for other than building purposes, such as for
preservation and protection of agricultural lands; environmentally sensitive
areas; natural resource areas; archeological, cultural and/or historic sites;
and open space areas shall be set aside through irrevocable conveyances
acceptable to the Planning Commission, providing that proof is made available
guaranteeing that the property shall remain undeveloped and unimproved (except
for agricultural and/or recreational purposes) in perpetuity.
   (d)   The existing and proposed public improvements intended to serve land
proposed to be subdivided shall conform to the provisions of the Comprehensive
Plan, Capital Improvement Program, develop program and any other plan(s)
adopted by the Village of Lordstown , and it is intended that these Regulations
shall facilitate the implementation of both the goals and objectives contained
in those plans, as well as the standards and provisions contained in building
and housing codes and zoning resolutions, where applicable.
(Ord. 56-2005.  Passed 10-3-05.)
1101.02  PURPOSE.
   These Regulations are adopted as minimum requirements for the regulation and
control of land subdivision within the incorporated areas of the Village of
Lordstown.  It is intended that the provisions of these Subdivision Regulations
shall be applied to secure and provide the following objectives:
   (a)   To provide the equitable handling, preparation and recording of all
subdivision plats by establishing uniform procedures and development standards
of design, construction, material specifications and performance guarantees for
all improvements on the land as herein required.
   (b)   To provide for the proper arrangement of streets and highways in
relation to those existing or planned, to produce a convenient and efficient
traffic circulation pattern.
   (c)   To require streets and highways to be of such width, grade,
construction, and location as to accommodate the prospective traffic generated
and to facilitate access by police, safety, and fire fighting apparatus.
   (d)   To provide adequate water supply, storm water management, erosion and
sediment control, sewage disposal, public utilities, and other public
improvements and services.
   (e)   To ensure that appropriate public facilities are available and will
have sufficient capacity to service the orderly extension of public
improvements and services at minimum cost and maximum convenience and to
prevent subdivisions of land that would place a disproportionate burden on
public funds for such extension.
   (f)   To improve the quality of life through the protection and preservation
of the environment, its resources, natural features, topography, wetlands,
water courses, vegetation and water table by preventing surface water and
subsurface water pollution, air, noise, light and visual pollution.
   (g)   To preserve and protect the geological, archeological, cultural, and
historic areas of significance.
   (h)   To regulate development in areas of geological concern, flood plains,
and in vicinities of previous mining activities.
   (i)   To avoid overcrowding of the land, population congestion, and to
promote security and safety from fire, flood, and other dangers.
   (j)   To encourage orderly and beneficial development in the Village and
provide adequate and convenient open space for traffic, utilities, access of
fire fighting apparatus, recreation, light and air.
   (k)   To protect the character, social and economic stability of the
Village, to conserve and enhance the value of the land and the value of
buildings and other improvements by providing the most beneficial relationship
between uses of land, buildings, traffic circulation and pedestrian movements.
   (l)   To require accurate surveying and monumentation for the preparation of
legal descriptions and subdivision plats, and to necessitate engineering design
and construction of improvements on the land as herein required.
      (Ord. 56-2005.  Passed 10-3-05.)
1101.03  AUTHORITY.
   By authority of Ordinance of the Village of Lordstown Council, adopted
pursuant to powers and jurisdictions vested through Chapters 711 and 713 of the
Ohio Revised Code and other applicable laws, statutes, resolutions, and
regulations of the State of  Ohio, as now existing or hereafter amended, the
Planning Commission does hereby exercise the power and authority within the
incorporated areas of the Village of Lordstown to review, approve, disapprove
or otherwise act upon subdivisions of land as defined in the Ohio Revised Code,
as now existing or hereafter amended. 
(Ord. 56-2005.  Passed 10-3-05.)
1101.04  JURISDICTION AND APPLICABILITY.
   These Regulations shall be applicable to all residential, commercial, and
industrial subdivisions of land located within the incorporated areas of the
Village of Lordstown in conformance with Section 711.001 et seq. of the Ohio
Revised Code.
(Ord. 23-2013.  Passed 4-1-13.)
1101.05  RELATION TO OTHER LAWS.
   (a)   The provision of these Regulations shall supplement any and all laws
of the State of Ohio, resolutions adopted by the Trumbull County Board of
Commissioners, the Council of the Village of Lordstown, the Village Board of
Public Affairs, or any and all rules and regulations promulgated by authority
of such law or resolution relating to the purpose and scope of these
Regulations.
   (b)   Whenever the requirements of these Regulations are at variance with
the requirements of other lawfully adopted rules, regulations, or resolutions,
the most restrictive or that imposing the highest standard shall govern unless
otherwise noted in these Regulations.
(Ord. 23-2013.  Passed 4-1-13.)
1101.06  VALIDITY AND SEPARABILITY.
   If, for any reason, any section, clause, sentence, paragraph or provision of
these Regulations be declared invalid or unconstitutional by a court of
competent jurisdiction, such decision shall not affect validity or legality of
these Regulations as a whole, or any part thereof, other than the part so held
to be invalid.
(Ord. 56-2005.  Passed 10-3-05.)
1101.07  SAVING PROVISION.
   These Regulations shall not be construed as abating any action now pending
under, or by virtue of, prior existing subdivision regulations, or as
discontinuing, abating, modifying or altering any penalty accrued or about to
accrue, or as affecting the liability of any person, firm, or corporation, or
as waiving any right of the Village of Lordstown under any section or provision
existing at the time of adoption of these Regulations, or as vacating or
annulling any rights adopted by any person, firm, or corporation by lawful
action of the county except as shall be expressly provided for in these
Regulations.
(Ord. 56-2005.  Passed 10-3-05.)
1101.08  ENACTMENT.
   These Regulations shall become effective from and after the date of its
approval, adoption, or amendment by the Village of Lordstown Council  after
public hearing and certification to the Trumbull County Recorder as required by
Chapter 711 of the Ohio Revised Code.  Henceforth, any other regulations
previously adopted by the Village of Lordstown shall be deemed repealed.  These
Regulations shall in no way affect any subdivision having received preliminary
plan approval prior to the effective date of these regulations or any amendment
thereto, provided, however, that no changes to the preliminary plan, as
approved, are introduced by the subdivider.
(Ord. 56-2005.  Passed 10-3-05.)
CHAPTER 1102
Administration and Enforcement
1102.00   Administration, enforcement and interpretation.
1102.01   Reservation and repeals.
1102.02   Amendments.
1102.03   Variances, exceptions and waivers of conditions.
1102.04   Expiration or extension.
1102.05   Voided applications.
1102.06   Recording a plat.
1102.07   Revisions of plat after approval.
1102.08   Sale and transfer of land.
1102.09   Fees and deposits.
1102.10   Violations and penalties.
1102.11   Written notice/stop action.
1102.12   Permits.
1102.13   Appeal.
 
1102.00  ADMINISTRATION, ENFORCEMENT AND INTERPRETATION.
   These Regulations shall be administered by the Planning Administrator of the
Village of Lordstown. The Planning Administrator, assisted by other government
agencies, legal counsel, and through other advice it may solicit, shall
administer and enforce these Regulations. Discretionary, conflicting, or
disputed aspects of these Regulations shall be interpreted by the Planning
Administrator or other individual designated by the Village of Lordstown Mayor
or the Chairman of the Planning Commission, in the absence of the Planning
Administrator.
(Ord. 56-2005.  Passed 10-3-05.)
1102.01  RESERVATIONS AND REPEALS.
   Upon the adoption of these Regulations, according to law, the Subdivision
Regulations of the Village of Lordstown adopted previously, are hereby
repealed.
(Ord. 56-2005.  Passed 10-3-05.)
1102.02  AMENDMENTS.
   The Village of Lordstown Planning Commission may, on its own motion and
after public hearing, amend, supplement or change these regulations in
accordance with the appropriate sections of the Ohio Revised Code.  However,
the Planning Commission may only amend, supplement, or change regulations
requiring the actual construction of improvements or posting of performance
guarantees, after review and adoption by the Village of Lordstown Council.
   Notice shall be given of the time and place of such public hearing by
publication in at least one newspaper of general circulation, thirty (30) days
prior to holding of said hearing and shall appear twice within the 30-day
period.  The amendment or amendments shall be on file in the office of the
Planning Commission for public examination during said thirty (30) days.
(Ord. 56-2005.  Passed 10-3-05.)
1102.03  VARIANCES, EXCEPTIONS AND WAIVERS OF CONDITIONS.
   Where due to exceptional topographic or other physical conditions the
Planning Commission finds that extraordinary and unnecessary hardship may
result from strict application of these Regulations, or the purpose of these
regulations may be served to a greater extent by an alternative proposal, it
may waive conditions to these Subdivision Regulations  provided that such
waiver will not be detrimental to the public health, safety, or welfare or
injurious to other properties.  Such waivers shall not have the effect of
nullifying the intent and purpose of these Regulations, any Comprehensive Plan,
or Zoning Resolution, when they exist.
   The hardship must be unique to the property for which the waiver is sought
and not applicable to any other property.  The hardship must result from the
strict application of these Regulations as distinguished from one of 
inconvenience due to the owner’s error, poor judgment or when the only
supporting evidence is that compliance would add to the development cost. 
   In granting waivers or modifications, the Planning Commission may require
such conditions, in its judgement, to secure substantially the objective of the
standards or requirements so waived or modified.
(Ord. 56-2005.  Passed 10-3-05.)
1102.04  EXPIRATION OR EXTENSION.
   Failure to comply with stated time periods of these Regulations shall result
in the expiration of the application and associated Planning Commission
approvals.  Before expiration, the subdivider may provide a letter and
extension fee stating why these time periods cannot be met and requesting their
extension.  The subdivider is solely responsible for knowing expiration dates
and meeting or extending them in accordance with these Regulations.  The
Planning Commission shall have no duty, obligation, or responsibility to remind
or notify subdividers of approaching expiration dates.
(Ord. 56-2005.  Passed 10-3-05.)
1102.05  VOIDED APPLICATIONS.
   An application shall become void and have no rights, standing, or status
under these Regulations, upon expiration, withdrawal, or disapproval.
(Ord. 56-2005.  Passed 10-3-05.)
1102.06  RECORDING A PLAT.
   No plat of any subdivision shall be recorded by the County Recorder of
Trumbull County or have any validity until said plat has received a final
approval in the manner prescribed in Chapter
1103 of these Regulations.  No conveyance of any parcel by metes and bounds,
not previously a lot of record, shall be recorded by the County Recorder of
Trumbull County unless such subdivision has been approved in the manner
prescribed by these Regulations.
(Ord. 56-2005.  Passed 10-3-05.)
1102.07  REVISIONS OF PLAT AFTER APPROVAL.
   No changes, erasures, modifications, or revisions shall be made in any plat
of a subdivision after approval has been given by the Planning Commission, and
endorsed in writing on the plat unless said plat is first resubmitted to the
Planning Commission.
(Ord. 56-2005.  Passed 10-3-05.)
1102.08  SALE AND TRANSFER OF LAND.
   No owner or agent of the owner of any land located within a proposed
subdivision shall transfer or sell any land by reference to, exhibition of, or
by the use of a plat of a subdivision before such plat has been approved and
recorded in the manner prescribed in these Regulations.  The description of
such lot or parcel by metes and bounds in an instrument of conveyance shall not
exempt the transaction from the provisions of these Regulations. (Ohio Revised
Code, Section 711.13) 
(Ord. 56-2005.  Passed 10-3-05.)
1102.09  FEES AND DEPOSITS.
